context: During the initial punk era, a variety of <b16_0>entrepreneurs<b16_0/> interested in local punk-influenced music scenes began founding <a5_0><b10_0>independent record labels<b10_0/><a5_0/>, including <a0_0><b19_0>Rough Trade<b19_0/><a0_0/> (founded by record shop owner <a6_0>Geoff Travis<a6_0/>) and Factory (founded by <a7_0><b13_0>Manchester<b13_0/><a7_0/>-based television personality <a1_0>Tony Wilson<a1_0/>). By <a2_0><a8_0><b15_0>1977<b15_0/><a8_0/><a2_0/>, groups began pointedly pursuing methods of <b11_0>releasing music independently<b11_0/> , an idea disseminated in particular by the <a3_0><b14_0><b18_0>Buzzcocks<b18_0/><b14_0/><a3_0/>' release of their Spiral Scratch EP on <a9_0>their own<a9_0/> label as well as the self-released 1977 singles of Desperate Bicycles. These DIY imperatives would help form the production and distribution infrastructure of post-punk and the <b12_0>indie music scene<b12_0/> that later blossomed in <b17_0>the <a4_0>mid-1980s<b17_0/><a4_0/>.
